title: Spike in weapons and drugs seizures in jails in crackdown on smuggling
text:

There has been a huge increase in weapons, drugs and phones seized in prisons after a high-profile clean-up project – but insiders say the war against contraband is far from won.

Jails participating in the Government’s £10million '10 Prisons Project' have seen a 6% rise in smuggled goods being confiscated, from 3,120 to 3,316 across six months.

At HMP Nottingham, seizures rose from 148 in the six months before the plan was introduced in August 2018, to 360 the following half year.

The number of knives and makeshift blades went from seven to 30, while seizures of spice, the so-called zombie drug, were up from 14 to 23.

An insider at the category B jail said: “Airport-style security and scanners isn’t stopping drugs coming in. There’ll always be ways to get stuff in.”

Total confiscations went from 298 to 353 at HMP Hull in the period, including a rise in spice and weapon seizures.

The number was also up at HMP Wealstun, West Yorks, from 356 to 392 and at HMP Leeds, where 569 illicit items were recovered, up from 552.

A source at one of the jails said: “For every one door shut another two open.”

The report by the Independent Monitoring Board found HMP Wealstun was so short of staff that inmates spent all day in their cells.

It said: “Levels of violence, self harm and the availability of drugs remained high, despite funding.”

Images published in the Mirror earlier this year ­illustrated the scale of the spice problem at HMP Humber, where almost a third of the 1,000 inmates claim to have developed a drug habit while inside.

The Ministry of Justice said: “We have taken decisive action to bolster security, strengthening our efforts to stop

contraband.”
description: EXCLUSIVE: The Government’s £10million '10 Prisons Project' has yielded results but a lot still needs to be done
